questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to dermatology OPD worried about his hair loss. He first noticed receding of the hairline over the bitemporal regions of his scalp five years ago, and then his hair has gradually become thinner over the crown of his head. Which drugs are most appropriate to treat this patient's hair loss?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Finasteride The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Androgenic alopecia. Finasteride It is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor Used as first-line therapy for men with androgenetic alopecia Mechanism: It decreases the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone ( as circulating androgen is responsible for the manifestations of this condition) Adverse effects : gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction (e.g., decreased libido, erectile dysfunction).

Highyeild:

Androgenic alopecia The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Androgenic alopecia. It is the most common cause of non-scarring alopecia. Androgenic alopecia aka Patterned type non-cicatricial alopecia Factors: Genetic + Androgens, which lead to Shortening of the anagen phase Miniaturization of the hair follicle Treatment: Minoxidil Finasteride Platelet-rich plasma therapy Hair transplant

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Griseofulvin: It is an antifungal medication and is used to treat fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails.Male pattern hair loss is a hormonal condition and is not caused by a fungal infection. Option B. Triamcinolone: It is a steroid medication that is used to reduce inflammation and itching associated with skin conditions such as eczema, psoriasis, and dermatitis. Option C. Levothyroxine: It is a medication that is used to treat an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with hair loss. He reports that he loose a good number of hairs every day. He asked the physician if he could regenerate his hair. In which of the following parts of hair are the regenerating cells present?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adamson's fringe In the hair follicle, Stem cells reside in a discrete microenvironment called the bulge called Adamson’s fringe. It is located at the base of the part of the follicle that is established during morphogenesis but does not degenerate during the hair cycle. Bulge SCs are more quiescent than other cells within the follicle.

Highyeild:

Hair anatomy: Longitudinal section

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought by his mother for a general Health checkup. The patient's hair follicles were checked during the examination to assess average growth and development. Most of the hairs on the patient’s body were light, short, and delicate as compared. Which of the following types of hair follicles can be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vellus The description given here is of Vellus hair. The light, short, fine hair covers much of a person's body . Its length and thickness will vary from person to person. The primary role of vellus hair is to protect the skin and keep the body warm.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tuberculid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen scrofulosorum Tuberculid is a hypersensitivity induced daughter lesion on skin. Mother lesion of tuberculosis may be hidden. Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of micropapular tuberculid.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man had a gradually progressive plaque on buttock for the last 3 years. The plaque had scarring in the centre as shown. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lupus vulgaris Lupus vulgaris is common on the buttocks in India due to practice of open air defecation. Lesions often have scarring in the centre and progress on the other end.

Highyeild:

Types of exogenous TB

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Tinea corporis will have clearing in the center and not scarring in the centre. It will also be itchy and scaly. Option B- Psoriasis will have red scaly plaques on the extensors like the elbow and the knee. There is no scarring on the skin. Option D- borderline leprosy will have annular, punched out lesions with sensory loss and thickened nerves.

Extraedge:

Central clearing = Tinea Central crusting = Leishmaniasis Central scarring = Lupus vulgaris Pick-up words in MCQs on lupus vulgaris • Central scarring • Healing in the center, extending on periphery • Buttocks or face
